intro: Gnaphalium pentheri, commonly known as the purple sandmat, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble small daisies. The plant produces small, showy purple to pink flowers that bloom in late summer and early fall. It is typically found growing in sandy or gravelly soils, often in desert or coastal environments. Gnaphalium pentheri is adapted to withstand drought conditions and has a low, sprawling growth habit.
